'There is NO such thing as NO DEAL' IDS HITS BACK at 'Project Fear'                Just get us out, say four in ten BritonsMs Harris hit back at the claims, saying that is was &ldquoclear what the public voted for during the 2016 referendum: &ldquoWe voted to leave the ECJ, leave the single market and leave the customs union.&ldquoIt was very clear on national TV, and in newspapers that we would be leaving those. I think independence comes when we have no connection to another country deciding our laws, that&rsquos what independence means, and that&rsquos what the general public thinks.But Mr Esler strongly objected to her comments saying: &ldquoThis isn&rsquot the Brexit that anyone voted for.Brexit news: Lucy Harris said calls for a 'people's vote' was  (Image: Channel 4 News)&ldquoWe want a people&rsquos vote on the deal negotiated by this government. What have you got against democracy?But Ms Harris took apart the former BBC presenter&rsquos argument for a further vote, arguing that the intention behind a &lsquopeople&rsquos vote&rsquo was to &ldquoide the Brexit vote.&ldquoWhat Gavin is advocating is a three-way vote, which you mean you have a clean Brexit, the Chequers deal, and then Remain in the EU.&ldquoWhat that basically means is that we&rsquore going to ide the Brexit vote, and then we&rsquore going to put ours there to give it more of a chance. That&rsquos basically what&rsquos happening, it&rsquos a trick, it&rsquos a trap, and people should not be falling for it.Earlier this year Ms Harris spoke to Express about her Brexiteer support group, saying that the impact on Leaver&rsquos lives and relationships was &ldquoabsolutely crazy.She said: &ldquoI get emails through, I get messages through saying stuff like &lsquoI&rsquom getting a orce, I&rsquove been kicked out my book club, I haven&rsquot got&nbspany more&nbspwork in the music industry because of this, I&rsquove been rejected for freelance work in journalism&rsquo.&ldquoAnd it&rsquos just got to the point where I just think it&rsquos crazy, absolutely crazy. To practice your democratic right and then have this backlash is discrimination.Under the Prime Minister&rsquos current Brexit proposals, the UK would maintain close commercial ties with the EU through a free trade area managed by a common rulebook.Mrs May&rsquos Chequers deal has sparked fury among Conservative Party members and let to the resignation of Brexit Secretary David Davis and Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson.A faction of Brexiteer dissidents, spearheaded by Jacob Rees-Mogg, is working to create an &ldquoalternative view to the Government&rsquos White Paper.Still in the development stages, the policy paper they aim to publish is understood to follow a Canadian-style free trade agreement, but only if the EU compromises on demands over the Irish border.

title: Brexit news BBC host Baroness Fairhead UK EU withdrawal exports UK economy latest
story: Baroness Fairhead delivered a brutal dig at BBC host Justin Webb after he questioned her claim Britain could improve its exporting capabilities in the aftermath of Brexit.The Trade Minister suggested the UK could use its withdrawal from the European Union to increase exports from 30 percent of GDP to reach the top of the pack of G7 countries.But when the Today programme host tried to challenge her claim, Baroness Fairhead said: I think Justin you keep wanting to have a renegotiation of the Brexit referendum.Our export performance is pretty impressive. We have grown 10 percent in the last year and we are now at 30 percent of GDP. That, however, puts us in the middle of the pack of the G7.                Brexiteer's BRILLIANT reason why UK should NOT have second vote                Brexiteer SHUTS DOWN Chuka Umunna in fiery Brexit debate Baroness Fairhead suggested the UK could use its decision to leave the EU to aim at expanding its exporting potential much like Germany had after 2000.She continued: We want to be towards the top of the pack. You single out Germany and you are completely right.Germany is at about 47 percent. But let's remember that only in 2000 Germany was at 30 percent.Mr Webb had previously questioned her claim of improved global trade opportunities, saying: Doesn&rsquot the German example just underline, for those who say we shouldn&rsquot be leaving the European Union, their case?Brexit news: Baroness Fairhead shut down Justin Webb after he challenged her  (Image: YOUTUBEThe Update&bullYOUTUBEAsia House)Which is you can have this great export performance and you can have it, indeed possibly you have it because you are inside the European Union?Mr Webb continued: It&rsquos on people&rsquos minds and as you know the Government is going to come out with its case for what happens in the case of no deal etc.These things are very much at the fore. And I&rsquom just wondering whether you are trying to look at the sunlit uplands of sometime in the future when in fact at the moment we face clear and present danger to exports?Baroness Fairhead, alongside Internationa Trade Secretary Liam Fox, is expected to outline the Government's long-term ambition to boost British business in the aftermath of Brexit.The Trade Department is seeking to expand exports to around 35 percent of British GDP from the record 30 percent of 2017.&nbsp

title: Brexit news UK EU financial services City of London no deal preparation latest
story: In a repeat warning, Downing Street maintains the EU&rsquos economy will suffer if the City of London is not offered a deal which goes beyond Brussels current standard for third countries.In a new document, the Government cited independent estimations showing Britain's financial industry trades as many euros in the UK than the whole of the eurozone combined.The document reads: &ldquoIf mutual market access is lost, independent analysis indicates economic benefits from UK FS activity relocating to the EU27 will be more than offset by negative fragmentation and lost efficiency impacts.The UK stresses the importance of the City of London as one of Europe's leading financial services hubs and how its business underpins the wider European economy.Brexit news: UK warns EU will suffer unless special City of London deal is agreed (Image: )UK-located banks underwrite around half of the debt and equity, manages &pound1.4 trillion of European assets, according to the Government presentation.It adds: TheCityUK estimates more than twice as many euros are traded in the UK than in all the euro-area countries combined.The Government have made it clear that the EU's normal financial services offer to third countries will not work.Once the UK leaves the EU, we will maintain strong and appropriate regulation of our sector, given the exposure of our economy to the fiscal risk it represents, the document states.                UK can become an 'exporting SUPERPOWER' after Brexit, vows Liam Fox                No deal Brexit will DESTROY EU warns Hunt - but UK will PROSPERThe UK hosts the world's most significant financial centre, with markets and products that are often very different from what is found elsewhere in the EU.These differences mean that rule taking &ndash in the sense of an open-ended commitment to adopt rules without having influenced their formation &ndash will simply not work.It is important to find a mutually acceptable solution that encourages us to work together constructively, protecting financial stability and respecting the principle of autonomous decision-making.Britain is keen to avoid signing up to the EU's standard regulatory equivalence arrangements for third countries because the European Commission has the power to withdraw equivalence rights at short notice with no consultation.The Government calls for both sides to agree sensible timetables for winding down activity and avoiding retaliation.Dominic Raab and Michel Barnier resume their Brexit negotiations in Brussels today (Image: )It outlines its wish for UK banks to have a similar relationship to the EU after Brexit as Japanese ones do.The document argues the EU's deal with Japan can be used as a precedent for a deal because it includes a commitment to take into account the impact of one another's decision-making.It was released ahead of Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab's visit to Brussels, where he will meet his EU counterpart Michel Barnier for a short negotiation round.Prior to their meeting, Mr Raab said: I am looking forward to meeting Michel Barnier today, to progress our negotiations on the outstanding withdrawal agreement, Northern Ireland and the future relationship.Confident we can strike a deal that's good for the UK and our EU partners.While hoping to strike a deal, Mr Raab will be able to take a no-deal Brexit to the negotiation table as Britain steps up its preparations for crashing out of the EU.On Thursday, over 80 preparation notices will be published by the Government to help businesses and citizens prepare for a no-deal scenario.

title: Liam Fox Brexit latest news UK EU Today Sky News European Union
story: Dr Fox made the comments to Sky News this morning as he announced ambitions to make the UK an &ldquoexporting super-power after Brexit.He will also commit minsters to a new ambition of ensuring exports account for at least 35 percent of economic output, up from the current level of 30 percent.Facing a grilling from Sky News presenter Sarah-Jane Mee, Dr Fox said he hoped it would not become harder to export good and services to the EU after the UK had left the bloc.He said: &ldquoThe question here is really, for both the UK and the European Union: is this to be a people&rsquos Brexit, where we get an open trading environment, where we can work towards our mutual prosperity?                Brexit poll: Nearly half want Britain to leave EU with or without deal                UK can become an 'exporting SUPERPOWER' after Brexit, vows Liam Fox&ldquoOr is this to be a bureaucrat&rsquos Brexit, about the purity of Brussels and the concept of an ever closer union?&ldquoThat&rsquos the real choice we have to make.He went on: &ldquoThe European Union also needs to think about the long-term economic viability and therefore on coming to an agreement with the United Kingdom, which is after all, the world&rsquos fifth biggest economy, but as we know the world&rsquos sixth biggest exporter, and the second biggest exporter of services.&ldquoWe need to look globally for the opportunities, there&rsquos a big world out there, there is a world beyond Europe, and a time beyond Brexit.Brexit latest: Dr Liam Fox said that the UK must start to look ahead to a time beyond Brexit.  (Image: Sky News )&ldquoWe need to prepare for the long terms to ensure prosperity in the United Kingdom, not just for the next three to five years, but for the next ten to fifteen to twenty years ahead.Dr Fox spoke to Sky as he announced hopes for Britain become an exporting superpower after leaving the EU.Setting out an optimistic vision of Brexit for business, the International Trade Secretary is to highlight how 400,000 more UK firms could start selling their products overseas.He will also commit minsters to a new ambition of ensuring exports account for at least 35 percent of economic output, up from the current level of 30 percent.Dr Fox will make the announcement in a keynote speech today to mark the launch of the Government Export Strategy designed to boost UK jobs and growth after the country quits the EU next March.In his speech to business leaders in London today, the Tory Cabinet minister is expected to say: &ldquoThe United Kingdom is a great exporting nation and our exporters lead the way, in creating jobs, raising wages and growing our economy.&ldquoUK businesses are superbly placed to capitalise on the rapid changes in the global economic environment and I believe the UK has the potential to be a 21st century exporting superpower&ldquoAs an international economic department, we are determined to support, connect and grow UK companies on the world stage through our international network.&ldquoAs we leave the EU, we must set our sights high and that is just what this Export Strategy will help us achieve.                UK warns Europe will suffer unless special City of London deal is made                Tough talk in the last days of the Leave negotiations Dr Fox has also suggested&nbspthe Government could seek to review Britain's migration policy after&nbspBrexit&nbspto match British employment opportunities.Asked about whether he agreed with the UK's immigration target of 100,000, the International Trade Secretary told&nbspLBC: I think that one of the things that was clear from the referendum was that the public do not want unlimited movement into the United Kingdom.The public can differentiate between people who come here with a job and will be contributing to the economy and those who under free movement were able to come to the United Kingdom and use our public services without ever having contributed to them.Well that's the government target and we'll be reviewing what we do post-Brexit.

title: brexit news fishermen wales trade deal eu deal
story: The Welsh Fishermen's Association (WFA) warned people would start going out of business after just four weeks if Britain leaves without a deal, with new customs checks and restrictions causing severe border delays.Sion Williams, a lobster and crab fisherman, who works near Nefyn, Gwynedd, in north Wales, said fishermen were increasingly concerned over the possibility of a no deal Brexit, which they claim would severely disrupt the transport of fish and other livestock.He insisted maintaining access to European markets was vital to UK's fishing sector, and expressed concerns over Britain leaving bloc without an agreement.He said: So much has been promised and people's hopes have been raised. I don't think anyone voted for things to get worse.                UK fishermen finally &lsquoBACK IN DRIVING SEAT&rsquo as Gove outlines Brexit                WE control our ports, not EU! MP lashes out at Brexit scaremongeringOf all the food producers exporting to Europe, the shellfish sector would be the most vulnerable if we have no deal.In Wales, 92 percent of registered vessels specialise in catching shellfish such as lobster, crab, whelks and mussels.In 2017, Welsh fishermen sold 90 percent of their shellfish to EU markets, contributing a total &pound38.8m to the fishing sector.Speaking to the BBC, Mr Williams added: Any delay in the transit of these commodities will cause a lot of problems as they are live shellfish and they need to be supplied as soon as possible.Fishermen say they would go out of business in just four weeks if Britain leaves the EU with no deal (Image: )If they're held up in ports, they can deteriorate, lose value and even die.It's been calculated that the industry would not be able to hold on more than four weeks of not being able to sell products into Europe.Because of the high cost of fishing enterprises, people expect to get a quick turnaround of money to support their businesses.He insisted the British and Welsh governments must provide financial assistance to UK's fishing industry if no Brexit agreement is made.                'SHARED challenge' May hits back after Italy demands UK take migran...                French fishermen shocked to find &lsquoDANGEROUS&rsquo WW2 bomb in their netMaintaining access to EU markets is vital to UK's fishing industry, Mr Williams warned (Image: )Mr Williams also said that tariffs of 6 percent for crabs and 8 percent for lobsters would be imposed if the UK does not arrange a substantial trade deal with the EU.A seafood restaurant chain in North Wales claimed the cost of shellfish would rise in the UK, declaring they were preparing for a Brexit backlash.But Gemma Webb, events manager at Dylan's, which has three sites in Criccieth, Menai Bridge and Llandudno, said local fishermen could see a good return from Brexit.She said: In some ways it could be good for the local fishing industry because surely if it is more difficult to get produce from abroad lots of restaurants here will be buying from local producers.British fishermen say shellfish produce would be most affected by a no deal Brexit (Image: )A Defra spokeswoman said leaving the EU would create a bright future for UK's fishing industry.She said: We are focused on getting the best possible deal when we leave the EU, which includes safeguarding the interests of our iconic fishing industry and maintaining consumer choice.A Welsh Government spokeswoman said: We are working hard with fishing communities to explore and, where possible, mitigate the impacts of a 'no deal' scenario but the threat is still very real.We have always been clear that full and unfettered access to the EU market must be maintained and are making the case for this with the UK government as the trade negotiations develop.

title: Brexit news Jeremy Kyle Alastair Campbell UK EU withdrawal latest leave news
story: Jeremy Kyle could be seen hilariously reacting to claims by Alistair Campbell suggesting that British voters are now starting to fear the consequences of Brexit.As Mr Campbell said public opinion on leaving the European Union is starting to change because the real questions that are now starting to arise are really starting to scare people.Mr Kyle could be seen listening to Mr Campbell during his first talkRADIO show last week scrunching his face and shaking his head in an unconvinced manner.&nbspThe radio host also challenged the former Blair spin doctor on both Remain and Leave campaigns almost lying. He said: So much wasn&rsquot said on either side, you said it already. Both sides almost lied, it was almost lies and the British people fell for it.'You want to RENEGOTIATE Brexit!' BBC host SHUT DOWN in heated rowProject FEAR 2.0: Philip Hammond told to REWRITE Brexit no deal planDo you think that if Brexit doesn&rsquot happen, we go back to it will the British people have a right to feel cheated? What if you and your lot are right and we get a second referendum, and by a narrow majority we decide to reverse that and stay, what about the people that voted the first time?A referendum is surely about the people getting what they decide.Mr Campbell, who has been tirelessly campaigning for a people's vote on the final terms of the Brexit deal, defended his position insisting people are entitled to change their minds and should be given the chance to do so.He said: You have to accept that we lost the referendum, and I do accept that, but I think the reason why the Brextremists are so desperate just to get this over the line in March next year is because they do worry that the will of the people is changing. And the people are entitled to change their minds.&nbspBrexit news: Jeremy Kyle showcased an extensive range of emotions as he listened to Campbell (Image: TALKRADIO)I don&rsquot think the world is going to end but I do think some time in history countries chose their own decline, whether by accident or by design. I do think this is the case of a country chasing its own decline.Will it work practically? I think one of the reasons public opinion is changing is because the real questions that are now starting to arise are really starting to scare people.He added: Not many weeks ago we had all these talks about stockpiling food and medicines. Nobody mentioned that during the referendum, either on the Leave side or Remain side.Despite his support for a re-run of the referendum, a Deltapoll survey of 1,094 adults last week revealed that one in four Briton want the Government to deliver Brexit, with only 31 percent backing a new in-out referendum.The survey found that 40 percent would prefer to leave the EU with or without a deal, with 15 percent supporting calls for a vote on the final deal reached with Brussels.

title: Brexit news Liam Fox migration policy target UK Government plan latest EU withdrawal
story: Liam Fox suggested the Government could seek to review Britain's migration policy after Brexit to match British employment opportunities.Asked about whether he agreed with the UK's immigration target of 100,000, the International Trade Secretary told LBC: I think that one of the things that was clear from the referendum was that the public do not want unlimited movement into the United Kingdom.The public can differentiate between people who come here with a job and will be contributing to the economy and those who under free movement were able to come to the United Kingdom and use our public services without ever having contributed to them.Well that's the government target and we'll be reviewing what we do post-Brexit.                'PEOPLE'S Brexit or BUREAUCRAT'S Brexit? - Liam Fox SLAMS EU 'purists'                'Free movement will NEVER end! Farage RUBBISHES May's Brexit plans Dr Fox continued: I think we need to look in the future at how we match our employment opportunities with our migration policy.The big problem with free movement from Europe was that people were able to come to Great Britain without having a job and they were able to use our public services like schools and hospitals and housing without ever having contributed.I don't think the public think that is fair and neither do I.The intervention from the Tory frontbencher came hours after Theresa May announced she would take the moral high ground during talks with Brussels and offer the three million EU citizens the right to stay in Britain even after a no deal.&nbspBrexit news: Liam Fox suggested the Government could review the migration policy (Image: SKY NEWS&bull)The unilateral proposal from Mrs May would allow European citizens to continue accessing public services like the NHS and claim benefits.&nbspThe proposal will be nestled within the first release of more than 80 papers, which the Government will publish on Thursday, outlining contingency plans for a &lsquono-deal&rsquo Brexit across different sectors.The idea was welcomed by staunch Brexiteer Jacob-Rees Mogg, who told The Times: &ldquoI have always thought we should make a unilateral offer in this area.&ldquoEU migrants came here legally and the UK is not the sort of country that applies retrospective legislation.&ldquoThey should have broadly the same rights as British citizens &mdash no better or worse.

title: EU news disintegration Brussels Juncker Italy Greece Brexit European bloc latest
story: European Union politics expert Hans Vollaard suggested Brussels will see the earlier stages of its end as EU member states begin to slowly demand more control back to national governments.Prof Vollaard claimed that rather than collapsing immediately, the EU political system would first be crippled by a series of partial exits fuelled by the dissatisfaction with the European project.Speaking exclusively to Express, Prof Vollaard said: What I expect is that many other actors, whether it&rsquos parties, governments, member states, are rather willing to stay in the European Union but are nevertheless very much dissatisfied about the EU.Instead of leaving completely, and using the option of a full exit, they&rsquod rather withdraw from the EU political system partially.                Brexiteer economist warns Brussels THIS could end bloc                Juncker warned EU 'QUASI-RELIGION' spells trouble for future of blocThe Dutch academic argued member states could recover autonomy from Brussels in different ways, including putting an end to compliance to EU law or stop paying into the common budget.Prof Vollaard, however, added that EU countries will continue to believe that partially remaining is better than leaving completely.He continued: Even in the case of Greece, the majority of the voters, parties and the Government in the midst of the Euro debt crisis, they still wanted to remain in the EU.That&rsquos because they can see that remaining is better, or less worse, than leaving.EU news: Hans Vollaard warned dissatisfaction with the EU could kickstart its dissolution (Image: )Prof Vollard also insisted that the dissatisfaction plaguing the EU could not be addressed due to the erging demands of single states clashing with other members.&nbspHe added: There are limited possibilities to fix the EU to such an extent the dissatisfaction will become less.If the Southern Europeans get what they want, meaning effective measures to address the migration problems which are key issues in Slovenia, Italy and Greece, that will require much more solidarity from the north of Europe and the north of Europe is less willing to do so.Effective ways to address this dissatisfaction are not available for the most dissatisfied voices.Forecasts of the dire future of the EU bloc have exponentially increased since the Brexit vote, with Brexiteers predicting Eurocrats could see their project fail before 2070.EU news: Prof Vollaard argued there are limited possibilities to fix the EU (Image: YOUTUBESharing Perspectives Foundation)Asked about previous forecasts on the future of the bloc, economist Andrea Hoss&ograve said: I said in my answer when talking about the 50-year horizon, I&rsquom not sure that the EU will be around in 50 years.I didn&rsquot give a year but actually, I do stand by that.The economist suggested the leadership of the EU had failed to consider the consequences that Brexit and key elections over the past year could have on the support for the European project.French President Emmanuel Macron spearheaded plans for the further amalgamation of the bloc with the role of a new eurozone finance minister.Ms Hoss&ograve continued: The leadership of the EU and the leading nations of the EU, who actually decide what happens there &ndash Germany and France &ndash they haven&rsquot thought the consequences of all these things like Brexit and the Italian elections and the tension with Central Europe, the Visegrad countries.They haven&rsquot drawn the conclusion that this direction of forcing the United States of Europe onto the people of Europe is not working.

title: Derbyshire news Fly tipping Netherfield Lane Sawley
story: View of Netherfield Lane near Sawley in Derbyshire where fly tippers have filled with waste (Image: SWNS)Netherfield Lane, in the village of Sawley, Derbyshire, has been dubbed the worst street in Britain for fly-tipping after being left strewn with 2,000 yards of abandoned waste.Shocking pictures show no less than seventy five huge piles of brazenly dumped trash in bushes and scattered along the roadside.The rubbish includes dangerous asbestos, sofas, chairs, baths, fridge, cupboards and mattresses as well as garden waste blocking off the quaint road.Mr Atkins, a production worker who discovered the rubbish, said it takes more than 15 minutes to get past the dumped waste on his bicycle.                RUBBISH! Travellers FURIOUS over litter on illegal camp site                LIGHTNING STRIKE: Freak UK weather as Nottinghamshire house SMASHEDHe said: It's disgusting. I've been cycling down there for the last 10 years and seen it slowly getting worse and worse.I phone the council and within a few days they come and clean it up, but then within a few days it fills up with rubbish again.They are putting more into the hedgerow now so you can get by. They used to dump it anywhere.One evening a van came flying down the road and just missed me. Someone had chopped a tree down and they had put it in front of the cycle path. It took me 30 minutes to get it out of the way.Netherfield Lane near Sawley in Derbyshire where fly tippers have filled with rubbish (Image: SWNS)I have spoken to the council a couple of times. The fields on one side are farming, and the farmer needs to use the road so you can't block it up completely.But you could get a two or three-tonne concrete block there so the farmer could lift it up and get by.That's what I suggested to the council but they said people need to get to the road. It's excuse after excuse.I think it's absolutely disgusting. Especially when it starts getting dark again - if the lighting is not good I will run straight into it.They could put CCTV cameras up on the main road so you can see every car coming down there.                Ebola outbreak in pictures: Latest pictures from Ebola outbreakLocal resident Barney Holtby, 69, who is a retired landscape gardener, added: I like to keep active and cycle along here but its just such an eyesore now.I used to walk by dogs but its too dangerous for that now, you just don't know what the might pick up.Its got to be the worst road in the country for fly-tipping. I have never seen anything like it in all my life. It looks like a mile-long landfill site.Councillor Alison Smith, deputy leader and portfolio holder for community services at North West Leicestershire District Council, said: Unfortunately, the largely disused Netherfield Lane has become a hotspot for fly-tipping in North West Leicestershire.We will be reviewing trail camera footage in an effort to identify the most recent offenders.Longer term we are supportive of discussions taking place between the county council's highways department and Aldi, who are currently developing a distribution centre nearby, regarding potentially blocking vehicular access to this road, preventing further fly-tipping.Netherfield Lane near Sawley in Derbyshire where fly tippers have filled with rubbish (Image: SWNS)Netherfield Lane near Sawley in Derbyshire where fly tippers have filled with rubbish (Image: SWNS)Netherfield Lane near Sawley in Derbyshire where fly tippers have dumped rubbish (Image: SWNS)Netherfield Lane near Sawley in Derbyshire where fly tippers have dumped waste (Image: SWNS)Netherfield Lane near Sawley in Derbyshire where fly tippers have filled with waste (Image: SWNS)Netherfield Lane near Sawley in Derbyshire where fly tippers have been dumping rubbish (Image: SWNS)Netherfield Lane near Sawley in Derbyshire where fly tippers have dumped waste (Image: SWNS)

title: mamma mia special show woman dementia
story: Daughter Rhiannon Lewis, left, with Shirley Lewis, her husband David and daughter Bethan (Image: TOM MARTINWALES NEWS SERVICE)When the classic Abba hits started to kick in, excited Shirley started to proudly sing and shout along with the lyrics she remembered from her younger days.But other audience members began huffing, puffing and tutting behind her.Daughter Rhiannon says she felt obliged to take her mum out of the Vue cinema in Cwmbran, South Wales, less than half way through.So Rhiannon was delighted when a cinema organised an inclusive event for her mum and some friends to watch Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again without having to be silent and still.                Let's open dementia cafes to help keep people active                Angela Rippon: I feel so lucky that mum always knew who I wasShe said: The stress just melted away - it wasn't an issue this time.We knew everyone in there was understanding.People were free to move around, there was a whole residential home of people that came and they were standing and talking and children dancing in the aisles.It was a different experience.Mum sang along this time to her favourite Mammia Mia but Cher's Fernando got us all going too.A manager at nearby Cineworld in Newport offered to host a dementia-friendly viewing after Rhiannon had a Facebook rant about the grumpy cinema-goers.Shirley was offered a special showing - and to invite more than 100 of her friends and fellow dementia sufferers.Rhiannon, 40, said: She loves Mamma Mia - it is her favourite. It is familiar to her and she loved it She can't really sing anymore but she shouts and calls out.A lady behind us made me feel really uncomfortable about that - she was moving around and huffing.My mum was really sad. She didn't want to leave the cinema.She yelled 'no' when we tried to get her out of her seat and she fought every step on the staircase.I made Nan my bridesmaid before I lose her to dementiaSanfillippo syndrome heartbreak: Mother reveals toddler&rsquos diagnosisTo people who didn't know, they must have thought my mum had a few beers before and was drunk.But she wasn't. It was just the effects of early onset dementia.She's only 68 and it looks like she has newly retired not a dementia sufferer. It was diagnosed when she was 57.She was angry for the rest of the day but due to her condition she couldn't work out why.At the time I was empathetic to the other guests in the cinema However on reflection I really wish I had told that lady so that she could have learnt her lesson in front of a room full of strangers. Rhiannon said: It means everything to me to see her happy and enjoying herself.Mamma Mia has an all-star cast including Meryl Streep and Pierce Brosnan (Image: )For those couple of hours she's not confused and is just in the moment and not having to deal with this daily battle she's going through. Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again is a musical romantic comedy and a sequel to the 2008 film Mamma Mia! The film features hit songs such as Knowing Me, Knowing You, Fernando, Dancing Queen and Super Trouper.There is also a star-studded cast including Amanda Seyfried, Colin Firth, Meryl Streep and Pierce Brosnan.Rhiannon, of Cwmbran, Gwent, said the film is her mum's favourite.She added: Mum loves music, dancing and even better watching musical films. Over time we have found that Mamma Mia both calms her down and makes her happy.

story: More than 80 cars were torched or vandalised in Gothenburg and other major cities west and south in Sweden on Monday, August 13.Fires were reported in Malm&ouml, Gothenburg and Helsingborg and shocking footage showed youths destroying vehicles in a shopping centre and hospital car park in Fr&oumllunda Torg in the west of the country.Youngsters dressed in black were also throwing rocks at the police to keep the firefighters from putting out the fires.The recent attacks have resulted in heated discussions among politicians in Sweden trying to find an answer to why it is happening.                SWEDEN RIOTS: Masked gangs set FIRE to 80 vehicles in shock violence                Sweden riots: Car fires, violence and ARSON ATTACKS hit streets bef... When are results announced?Sweden riots: Fires were reported in Malm&ouml, Gothenburg and Helsingborg (Image: TWITTER: JJOHANJJANSON)&ldquoThis is a development that has been ongoing and escalating in Sweden for years, with groups of immigrant descent who control the drug trade.&ldquoSocial democrats think these attacks look too advanced for a couple of normal people to do so it must be racist propagandists.The MP explained that local drug gangs have become a huge issue in recent years and that the left-wing government, as well as official forces, has been denying and overlooking the problems for years.The &ldquotalking class, as Mr Bali calls them, are putting out a false reality saying Sweden is safer than ever.Sweden riots: Conspiracy theories have surfaced around the reason for the arson attacks (Image: AFP)That is not the case, according to the outspoken politician.&ldquoWe have huge problems with gangs and they are becoming younger and younger. Some are recruited when they are 11 and 12-years-old, he said.Mr Bali said to end the violence and stop the gangs, Sweden need stricter gun laws, more harsh sentencing and bigger consequences.&ldquoThe sentencing system is a joke, even the criminals laugh at it, he said.&ldquoThey get a slap on the wrist in court and walk out.&ldquoWhen it comes to the liberals of the left, it is unbelievable that a couple of suburban kids can say &lsquohi let&rsquos burn some cars&rsquo &ndash therefore they think it&rsquos organised.Sweden riots: Prime Minister Stefan L&oumlfven talks to the Swedish press after the arson attacks (Image: AFP)With less than three weeks to go before the Sweden election, it is still not possible to say who will win.The Social Democrats might have its worst election ever, losing foothold in areas unimaginable only two to three years ago.In the months before the election, Swedes have seen the eurosceptic party Sweden Democrats (SD) popularity rise, topping the polls in June and July.But in the latest poll the SD slid back to third place after topping the three previous surveys.Sweden will go to the polls on September 9.

title: Venezuela Bolivar devaluation impact world economy
story: Venezuela has undergone drastic measures to combat hyperinflation as the country suffers from shortages in both food and medicine.The South American country has seen its fair share of turbulent times since the death of former president Hugo Chavez.Venezuela has been hit by dramatic riots as violence floods onto the streets, with hundreds being killed in police crackdowns over the past five years.Migrants are now flooding into Brazil following fresh uncertainty after new bank notes were issued this week.And the high numbers of people trying to flee the economic collapse is only serving to stoke regional tensions, with violent clashes taking place at makeshift migrant border camps.                Venezuela&rsquos new currency is &lsquoSCAM&rsquo and will NOT fix economic chaos                 Venezuela currency devaluation: What is happening in Venezuela?Overnight, Venezuela slashed five zeros from the bolivar as part of a broad economic plan to tame hyperinflation that economists say is likely to escalate the ongoing crisis.In March 2016, one bolivar was the equivalent of 11p in the UK - but now the currency has dropped so low, it equates to 0.0000031p.The new measures to end the depression are so drastic , they may have the potential for major worldwide implications.Will Venezuela devaluation cause global meltdown?Venezuela currency devaluation: Will President Maduro's decision have WORLD implications? (Image: )At the moment, the strongest and most immediate impact the devaluation will have is on the local population.Venezuela&rsquos already ailing economy has pushed many people to flee the country and many more are expected to leave as inflation continues to rise.About 900 Venezuelans were expected to arrive in the border town of Pacaraima on Monday, August 20 - a day before shops and banks were due to reopen following the bank holiday.Extra security forces have been sent to the town, where many of those crossing over say they are hungry and have had no access to medical supplies.In Pacaraima on Saturday, several migrant encampments were attacked by residents following reports a local restaurant owner had been badly beaten by Venezuelans.And the economic situation is only worsening.                Venezuela hyperinflation CRISIS: Reforms could see oil price riseVenezuela's public is likely to be plunged into further chaos as poverty climbs (Image: )Bloomberg&rsquos Caf&eacute con Leche index currently has Venezuelan inflation at 108,000 percent per year.The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has pointed to an excess of one million percent inflation for the country this year.Devaluation will kick the current value of 285,000 per dollar to 6 million.The seemingly huge 3,500 percent wage increase was an attempt to offset any damage but is still the equivalent of just $30 (&pound23) a month.Venezuela&rsquos latest decision is most likely to impact domestic rather than international business.President of Caracas-based market researcher Datanalisis, Luis Vicente Leon, took to Twitter to outline future problems for domestic businesses.Venezuela's Bolivar is now more valuable crafted into other items (Image: )He said: &ldquoThe transition to apply the concrete elements of the proposal: exponential increase in salaries, massive requests for advancement of benefits and increase and change of frequency of tax payments puts companies in a situation of catastrophic cash flow.Maduras&rsquo proposed new currency, the Sovereign Bolivar, will be pegged to cryptocurrency Petro.The country&rsquos economy is already suffering as their most important export, oil, is seeing low production due to a shortage on technology and expertise.The IMF predicts the situation will likely get worse for Venezuela rather than the rest of the world.IMF Western Hemisphere department director Alejandro Werner, revealed in a blog post that the latest disaster could be on historical proportions.In the post, he said: &ldquoWe are projecting a surge in inflation to 1,000,000 percent by end-2018 to signal that the situation in Venezuela is similar to that in Germany in 1923 or Zimbabwe in the late 2000&rsquos.A recent poll found that 90 percent of Venezuelans are now living in poverty and a further 60 percent are unable to purchase food.It seems the prospects for the once wealthy country are at free-fall, but the rest of the world is yet to feel the impact.

title: EU news Germany Heiko Maas Poland European Union judicial reform
story: German foreign minister Heiko Maas visits former concentration camp Auschwitz (Image: )Heiko Mass made the intervention ahead of his second trip to Poland to meet Polish counterpart Jacek Czaputowicz and visit the former German concentration camp Auschwitz.Mr Mass stressed European values are non-negotiable and if they are subject to pressure by inidual member states there must be a dialogue with Brussels to resolve the issue.The European Commission, Brussels&rsquo powerful executive, have threatened legal action after Warsaw&rsquos ruling Law and Justice party slashed the retirement age of supreme court judges from 70 to 65, which forces 27 of the 74 sitting judges to retire.Critics, including the Commission, claim the move weakens the independence of the country&rsquos judicial system.When asked if the Polish authorities pose a threat to the EU, Mr Mass said: &ldquoEuropean values, such as freedom, the rule of law and respect for human rights, are at the heart of the European Union and are not negotiable.&ldquoIf European values are subjected to pressure in inidual member states, then this must be the subject of dialogue between member states and institutions at EU level.&ldquoAs part of the ongoing rule of law protection, we support the dialogue between the European Commission and the Polish government and we hope that the concerns expressed by the Commission will be resolved.Despite the threat of legal action from Brussels, Polish prime minister Mateusz Mateusz declared his country sets standards in the EU.                EU take on POLAND: Rebel Warsaw faces court case                 Senior judges plot to boot Warsaw off powerful European judicial bodyHe told supporters at an election event that Warsaw sets the standards, ideas and proposals that are mimicked across the whole of Europe.&ldquoDuring the times of our predecessors, Poland was a bit of the parrot of Europe &ndash we only imitated, he said.&ldquoToday we set the standards, ideas and proposals. And these ideas are copied throughout Europe, for example in the field of the VAT or the fight against tax havens.The Commission, however, will continue its crackdown on Warsaw over its judicial reform.Poland prime minister Mateusz Mateusz said his country sets the EU an example (Image: )The EU&rsquos powerful executive announced Poland had one month to amend the law or face being dragged in front of the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg.Officials said: &ldquoThe response of the Polish authorities does not alleviate the Commission&rsquos legal concerns.Last year, Brussels took an unprecedented step to consider the use of Article 7 &ndash which could lead Poland&rsquos EU voting rights being removed &ndash as a threat against the new legislation.The Commission sent a letter of formal notice to Warsaw on July 2 and they said that Poland&rsquos reply to this fails to &ldquoalleviate the commission&rsquos legal concerns.Brussels has constantly said the court reforms are &ldquoincompatible with EU law as it undermines the principal of judicial independence, including the irremovability of judges.

title: british voters give brexit verdict
story: Nearly half of Brits think we should leave the EU on March 29 with or without a deal, a Sun on Sunday poll reveals.They are sick of Brussels bullying and resistant MPs stalling — and simply want ministers to deliver.The mood of the nation is hardening after two years of bitter rows and fruitless negotiations since the historic referendum result.An overwhelming 62 per cent say they have not changed their minds. Those who have are mostly Remainers who would now vote Leave.Many people are deeply sceptical about the tedious stumbling blocks that have bogged down the process.Almost half — 48 per cent — think the political classes are deliberately making heavy weather of Brexit in the hope it will convince the public to change their minds.Six in ten believe the EU is out to punish the UK by refusing to compromise in talks on trade and free movement, our Deltapoll survey says.But the vast majority are convinced a departure deal will be hammered out in the end, even if it takes longer than expected.Former Cabinet minister Priti Patel last night said: “The Sun on Sunday’s poll shows that the British people ultimately believe we can build a stronger future for our country outside the EU.Nearly half of adults believe the weather goes in cycles and that heatwaves come around from time to time.Barely a third of voters believe the human race is responsible and that we will have more extreme temperatures unless we act soon.Our poll found that a majority of 18 to 24-year-olds blame global warming for the hottest British summer since 1976.But in every other age group, most people think it has little or nothing to do with climate change.Six in ten over-55s believe it was “just another hot summer”.“It is clear that most people are sick to the back teeth of being ­bullied by the EU and listening to politicians at home erecting all kinds of obstacles to prevent them honouring the referendum result.“The Government should sit up and heed the results of this poll. That means being tougher in negotiations with Brussels and doing what the nation voted for — to get Britain out of the EU.”Most people — 55 per cent — are against a second in-out referendum, according to our poll.Forty per cent think we should just leave in 222 days’ time as planned with or without a deal.Fifteen per cent want a vote on the final deal, but not a re-run on whether or not Britain leaves the EU.Overall, only 13 per cent have changed their minds on Brexit since the referendum on June 23, 2016. Most of those were once Remainers. Fifteen per cent of them admit to having shifted their view — equivalent to 2.4 million people.That compares with just 11 per cent of Brexit backers, 1.9 million, who have had a rethink.Ex-Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith said the poll had “nailed the lie” that many people regret voting Leave.Deltapoll director Martin Boon said the findings show most people are taking a tougher stance on Brexit.He added: “Half the public believe themselves to be under siege from the political classes trying to change their minds.“But the message they are sending back is that they haven’t changed their minds and the likelihood is they won’t.”Voters are evenly divided on whether there will be a hard border after Brexit. Twenty-two per cent say there will, 21 per cent say otherwise.There is also a split over whether leaving the EU will prove a historic mistake. Forty-four per cent think it will, 30 per cent believe it will not. One statement united 59 per cent of voters — “I’m really bored by Brexit.”Separately, our poll found that most people think former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson was right to raise the difficult and sensitive issue of women wearing burkas. Two-thirds believe he was right to start a debate about the Muslim veil.But some say he should say sorry because he went “over the top” by comparing wearers to “bank robbers” or “letterboxes”. Half of Tory supporters and 36 per cent of all voters believe his remarks were right and he has nothing to apologise for.A further 28 per cent say he went a little too far with his language and should admit it.He gets no support from 23 per cent, who say his remarks were offensive and he should say sorry.Deltapoll interviewed an online sample of 1,904 adults aged 18+ from August 14 to 16. Results have been weighted to the profile of all GB adults.The Labour leader has defied the odds after damaging revelations about the friends he keeps.Half of voters believe Labour has a problem with anti-Semitism. More than a third say Mr Corbyn is part of that problem.But a Sun on Sunday Deltapoll has Labour three points ahead of the Tories.If there were an election tomorrow, Labour would be 31 seats short of a majority but with enough MPs to form a government with Scottish Nationalist support.Tory backing has been sapped as traditional supporters switch to Ukip in protest over the PM’s weak handling of Brexit.There is little to celebrate for any of the party leaders who all get negative popularity ratings.Mr Corbyn scores minus 35, while Theresa May is on minus 26 — only two points better than floundering Lib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable.Today, a Sun on Sunday poll shows that idea to be total codswallop.Voters simply want our politicians to get on with delivering Brexit.The majority of people have not changed their mind since the referendum.Our poll shows those that have are mostly Remainers who would now vote Leave.Project Fear has never worked, and it is not going to suddenly start working now. The public are wise to it.Our poll makes it clear that fudging Brexit would unleash serious anger among the electorate. The Government should take notice.Almost half of voters already reckon that the political classes in Britain are making heavy weather of Brexit, in the vain and misguided belief that they can get the public to change their mind.Meanwhile, the drop in support for Theresa May in the polls and Ukip’s rise is a further indication of what the public thought of her Chequers proposals.Millions more will abandon the Tories if Brexit ends up being fudged.Remoaners and Brussels have done their best since the Leave vote to make us think we made a terrible mistake and that the cards are stacked in the EU’s favour.Well, today’s poll is clear.We didn’t and they’re not.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: young women getting 99 botox
story: After all, in the era of Love Island and social media, we’re all potential celebrities now. Even those of us who will never hit the big time have an Instagram audience waiting to “like” our every selfie.So this is just the logical next step towards making cosmetic surgery available to the masses, rather than the few.Some have argued that Superdrug Botox is actually a good thing, because it bridges the gap between the elite Harley Street options — where you pay several hundred pounds for an appointment with an “aesthetic doctor” — and the more backstreet treatments carried out by hairdressers with just a few hours of training.I disagree. Being able to buy a syringe or two of Botox when you are out shopping for your hairspray legitimises — and normalises — the act of injecting poison in your skin in the name of beauty.Being able to buy Botox over the counter, so to speak, makes it seem like no big deal — just another tick in the “maintenance” box, and as reasonable as tinting your lashes or getting your ears pierced.And that is the problem. All decisions we make about our appearance boil down to personal choice. And if it makes someone feel better to tinker cosmetically or surgically with their natural looks, that’s their choice. No one should judge them for it.But there is a wider problem.Increasingly, women think that whatever they look like naturally isn’t good enough. More and more, the “solution” is invasive cosmetic enhancement.A mainstream shop making Botox available for less than 100 quid is surely only going to add to the pressure some women feel to change their appearance using more than just make-up.Superdrug presents itself as responsible because it will refuse to treat under-25s, when other clinics will.That is shocking — not so much that some clinics WILL treat under-25s but that anyone so young could think they need Botox.You can’t blame Superdrug for this epidemic. It is simple supply and demand.The question is: Why the growing desire among women to look frozen?It’s not like you can get away with saying you’ve not had it when you have, because it’s so obvious.I’ve got a friend whose husband jokes that she needs to hold up little signs saying “happy” or “angry” when she feels an emotion, since her face is so paralysed by botulism.While I’m a big believer in your body, your choice, I’m also a believer in scratching the right itch.The truth is if you feel good about yourself, you look good. If you feel bad and lack confidence, nothing, no amount of Botox or fillers, will ever change that.Just look at Meg from Love Island, above, who, even after an estimated £40,000 worth of plastic surgery, is still massively insecure.Because it’s not what’s on the outside that counts, it’s what’s on the inside.The problem is our society tends to give far too much weight to the outside. That is especially the case for women, but increasingly for men, too.I realise all of this is easy to say, harder to act on. I’m as susceptible as the next person to comparing myself with ­others more beautiful — and possibly more airbrushed — and finding myself lacking.I’m just glad that, when that happens, I know the thing that will make me feel better is far more likely to be self-acceptance than Botox.After all, if you tighten a prune you don’t get a grape — you just get a tight prune!So the really big question is, how to achieve self-acceptance when we are surrounded by all these images of perfection?Well, we are all on our own journey with that one but I’ve got some suggestions which might help.The first is to focus on what you have, rather than what you don’t. And the second is to never, ever compare yourself to anyone else.Forget Botox, you can have that advice for free.You’re welcome.We all enjoyed cheering on the Three Lions players that would quickly become our heroes during the World Cup in Russia this summer.Sadly, those heady days are over and we were reminded of the seamier side of sport this week with the arrest of England rugby union ace Danny Cipriani.His embarrassing brawl outside a Jersey nightclub came hot on the heels of England cricket’s Ben Stokes’ trial over his clash with two men during a night out.Stokes was cleared, but what links these sorry sagas is our drinking culture, which dictates that consuming excessive amounts of alcohol is a normal way of letting off steam.Sportsmen are supposed to be role models, as they influence young people and need to keep themselves in good physical shape.But as long as we think it is OK to binge and push our bodies to the limits rather than sip a few drinks, then violence, injuries and stupid mistakes will continue to be a regular feature of our nights out.And if you are an England sports star, then public shame is just one of the tragic consequences – along with the end of your career – that you might have to face.Why should anyone be surprised at the news that sexual harassment in the police force is rife?Let’s face it, it happens everywhere. So why should the police be any exception?I thought they might hold themselves to higher standards. But no.A new survey reveals that dirty jokes, inappropriate touching, leering and being pressured to have sex are daily issues for many police staff.In a survey of almost 1,800 police staff in England, Wales and Scotland, half had heard sexualised jokes and one in five had received a sexually explicit email or text from a colleague.Shockingly, one in five had also been touched in a way that made them feel uncomfortable.Our head of police at West Ham is a woman.She is smart, tough, brave and would never put up with this type of behaviour.Part of the problem is that many women accept these actions as “normal” and don’t even know how to object. We must learn to stop putting up with it.But it is much more important that men learn what is OK and what is not.End of.Jacinda Ardern – the Prime Minister of New Zealand, who has continued to work since becoming a mother in June – was criticised this week for “using her baby as a prop” after she was seen breastfeeding her daughter at a public meeting.I guess whoever coined that phrase has never had the experience of looking after a baby who needs to be fed – right NOW.Nor will they have dealt with the very loud consequences of that failing to happen.Instead, what about congratulating Jacinda on doing such a great job of being a working mum?We said farewell to two legends last week, let’s remember them with this wonderful meme....So interesting that the day after A-level results arrived, more than 26,000 university places were still available.An Ipsos Mori poll found that while most students still think university is “important”, that is down from 86 per cent five years ago to 75 per cent now.Since a degree is expensive – and no guarantee of a job – you can see why people are questioning the validity of one.However, there is no viable alternative.There are just 10,000 degree-level apprenticeships available, compared with 300,000 university places, according to Sir Peter Lampl, of the Sutton Trust.We need to think how we prepare young people for work and we need more technical qualifications at degree level that offer the chance of a bright future.GOT a story? title: remoaners dream second referendum codswallop
story: Today, a Sun on Sunday poll shows that idea to be total codswallop.Voters simply want our politicians to get on with delivering Brexit.The majority of people have not changed their mind since the referendum. title: theresa may tory leadership contest trevor kavanagh opinion
story: While Theresa May tours the capitals of Europe looking for peace on Brexit, war has broken out between diehard Remainers and fervent Brexiteers.Ex-Ukip leader Nigel Farage has stormed back into the fray with Vote Leave II, a remake of his 2016 referendum triumph.In the pro-Brussels corner, Superdry fashion tycoon Julian Dunkerton is forking out £1million for what must surely be a futile, last-ditch bid to keep Britain in the EU.And just to make things extra interesting for the party conference season, the stampede for Mrs May’s Tory crown is already unstoppable.Indeed, the question is no longer if, or even when, the contest takes place. It is whether the PM herself will seize the initiative and signal her own plan to jump before she is pushed.The undeclared contest has transformed Britain’s negotiating stance — from Theresa May’s meek, slow-motion surrender to a strident demand for a decent, honourable settlement. The good news is that while MPs have been away on holiday, Brussels has begun to blink.At long last it has dawned on our EU neighbours that they have more to lose from a messy Brexit than we do.Forfeiting the UK’s £40billion ransom payment — plus our annual £12billion contribution — would instantly cripple the EU expansionary budget plans and plunge poorer nations such as Greece into crisis.Car and pharmaceutical giants, not to mention French farmers, who export vast stocks to the UK, would be plunged into crisis. Cooperation on crime, security and defence would be at risk. Governments across Europe are now piling pressure on Brussels to see sense.Tory leadership wannabes have sniffed the way the wind is blowing.The Tories won’t pick another Remainer as party leader. Nor does this Government have a prayer at the next election unless it can see off Nigel Farage and his Ukip insurgents with a deal that satisfies the 52 per cent who voted Leave.This explains a sudden enthusiasm at the top for stating the blindingly obvious: Britain will survive a clean Brexit, while an obstructive Brussels will be diminished.After two years of being bossed around by EU bully Michel Barnier, senior Cabinet ministers are coming out as born-again Eurosceptics. Foreign Secretary and repentant Remainer Jeremy Hunt admits Britain will experience some turbulence, but says the EU will be damaged “for a generation”.His warning is echoed by Brexit supremo Dominic Raab, who has rubbished “Project Fear” stories about food and medicine shortages.While loyally insisting a deal is “still the most likely outcome”, Mr Raab insists Britain will cope with the alternative.Hunt and Raab are now openly jockeying for the top job — along with Home Secretary Sajid Javid, Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson, Treasury chief Liz Truss and a host of others.Significantly, Michael Gove seems out of the race after endorsing Mrs May’s Chequers sellout. So where does this leave Boris Johnson? If tens of thousands of grass- roots Tory supporters have anything to do with it, he would be way out in front. As things stand, they don’t.BoJo is out of office and fighting confected outrage over Muslim face masks. Enemies such as the priestly Dominic Grieve threaten to quit the party if he is elected.Under present rules, Boris needs enough support from fellow MPs to be one of the two candidates submitted to party members for a final verdict. His rivals will do anything to stop him — which is why party activists are demanding rule changes to allow any MP with 20 votes to enter the final ballot.Boris has gone quiet — but not for long. He is reportedly planning a nationwide tour — complete with bright-red battle bus — trashing Mrs May’s Chequers deal and calling for a clean Brexit.There will be plenty of opportunities for car-crash interviews and zipwire-style TV images. But the bookies aren’t the only ones making BoJo the clear favourite as Britain’s next Prime Minister.He names Somalis, Ethiopians, North and Central Africans and Afghans as being responsible for the knife-gang slaughter of young black and Asian men.“Race is part of the picture,” says the equality campaigner. “Failing to point this out impedes the fight against these crimes and imperils yet more children of colour.”He is right, isn’t he?But how long before this decent black man is himself accused of racism for daring to tell this unvarnished truth?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: breastfeeding mums told by swimming pool staff to leave claim they were discriminated against
story: Natalie Forester and Chloe Hattersley were feeding their children at Dimensions, in Burslem, Stoke-on-Trent, when staff asked them to leave the pool.The council-owned facility says that breastfeeding is discouraged for the health and comfort of the child and to avoid the risk of the child regurgitating or vomiting in the pool.However the mums claim that the council is breaching the Equality Act 2010.Natalie, 30, who is a mum of three and was at the pool feeding toddler Josiah at the time, told the Stoke Sentinel: “There were about five other parents in the pool with their children. The rest of the pool was closed to the public.“Josiah was distressed so I thought I would give him some milk.“I thought if we got out he would get cold, so I moved away and turned my back to the group.“I was only going to feed him for a couple of minutes to comfort him.“The teacher came over and said I couldn’t do it in the pool and I would have to sit on the side. I was made to feel like I was doing something wrong.“I didn’t want a confrontation so I moved, which I’m annoyed about now. I felt degraded.”Natalie asked for a copy of Dimensions’ breastfeeding policy, and found the rule under the Food and Beverage section.She said: “Stoke-on-Trent has one of the lowest breastfeeding rates in the country and they should be encouraging people, not doing this.”First-time mum Chloe, of Middleport, had a similar experience while at an Aquatots session with her 17-month-old son Milo.The 19-year-old said: “I have breastfed in the water before, but on this occasion a lifeguard shouted across the pool to me to stop doing it.The Equality Act 2010 states that it is discrimination to treat a woman unfavourably because she is breastfeeding.Councillor Anthony Munday of Stoke-on-Trent City Council said: We have many areas at our poolside where breastfeeding can take place and actively promote and support this, although we do ask that breastfeeding doesn’t happen in the pool.We take on board the feedback from mums and will do more to work with them to understand their views and consider if this is something that needs to change for the future.We are sorry if this has caused any distress to any of our pool users.

title: julian dunkerton brexit
story: A multimillionaire with a bombshell fashion designer wife two decades his junior - who dresses Meghan Markle and the Beckhams - and whose divorce from his ex cost him more than £50 million.While hes a passionate advocate of the EU, its been pointed out that Superdrys clothes arent even made in Europe - theyre being made in India, Mauritius and Malaysia.Not that thats going to stop Julian Dunkerton - whos worth £441m - from wading into the Brexit debate, even though a Sun on Sunday poll found that nearly half of Brits want to leave the EU with or without a deal.So who are Britains filthy rich fashion power couple youve never heard of?Last weekend, Jade Holland Cooper, 31, walked down the aisle in what appeared to be a custom-made Galia Lahav backless dress, costing around £15,000.No expense was spared as she accessorised with a pair of Chanel diamond earrings and choker, as well as diamond-encrusted Louboutin heels.The couple were surrounded by candlelight and hundreds of wild English flowers for the celebrations at their home in Gloucestershire.Later on Craig David serenaded guests and Idris Elba jumped on the DJ decks.Now the pair are spending their honeymoon in an idyllic thatched villa in the Maldives - and it was out here that Julian, 53, donated £1m to the Peoples Vote Campaign.Like George Soros before him, Julian is the latest mega wealthy businessmen-turned-political meddler hellbent on overturning the Brexit decision.And the couple are well-accustomed to luxury getaways.Jades Instagram is filled with glamorous trips and shes more than happy to show off her low-cut tops whether shes with her squad in Mykonos or re-calibrating in Greece.But it wasnt always this way.Julian is the son of a BBC producer Ivor and grew up in Twickenham.After his dreams of being a doctor were dashed when he failed his A-Levels, he borrowed £2,000 from his dad, rented a retail unit for £30-a-week and lugged bin bags of clothes across London.He set up a market stall, named Cult Clothing Co, before meeting his business partner James Holder and setting up Superdry in 2003.By 2010, it was valued at £400 million on The London Stock Exchange.Jade, by contrast, grew up on a farm in Suffolk, the daughter of a wealthy farmer and a designer mother, who worked for Elton John and Harrods.She was privately educated and made her social debut in Country Life magazine, after being pictured for their famous ‘Girls in Pearls’ feature – a portrait of  the Royals or well-heeled, of-the-moment socialites.After dropping out of the Royal Agricultural College in her second year, Jade began designing trendy tweed clothing for city types who owned country boltholes, and people who attended events such as horse racing, polo, and shooting.She told The Times: [At the RAC] I realised we were all wearing the same bog-standard, green, itchy masculine tweed. I saw a gap in the market.The woman I want to dress [is] someone whos probably got a house in the country. She lives a dual life and wants to look sharp in both. It was me, really.The couples famous acquaintances dont stop at having Idris Elba and Craig David perform as a double act at their wedding.Jades luxury label has become hugely popular on the toff circuit since it launched in 2008.Megan Markle wore one of her coats earlier this year and her tweed creations have been seen on everybody from her old friends, Made in Chelsea’s Ollie Locke and Georgia Toffolo, to Love Island’s Chris Hughes, and Zara Phillips.When Becks and his boys were recently photographed trying to blend into Cotswolds life, the baker boy caps came from Holland Cooper.In February 2016, Julian was forced to sell four million shares, costing a £52 million stake, to fund his divorce from his wife of just under seven years, Charlotte Abbot, with whom he has two children.It was a staggering sum, especially given the couple only married in 2009, long after his clothing brand was off the ground.Earlier this year he reportedly cashed in £17.8 million of shares in what was thought to also be a bill for the same divorce.During their time together they lived in a £3.25m seven-bedroomed sprawling farmhouse in Gloucestershire.Although she has since deleted her Instagram account, the Daily Mail reported that Charlotte had then herself moved on to dating a younger man, posting pictures of them skiing and at black tie events together. Newlywed Jade says of marrying a man so much older than her: The age gap doesnt worry me. When you put it on paper you go Oooh, but I never think about it when were together. We have so many synergies and our morals are very similar.Since stepping back from Superdry, Julian is now pursuing cider brewing and a boutique chain of hotels, restaurants and pubs.But whatever happens with the Brexit negotiations, you can be sure that it wont make much of a dint in their ultra-glam and jet-set lifestyle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast temeratures plummet ahead of bank holiday weekend
story: The mercury is expected to reach a muggy 28C on Wednesday before more brisk autumn temperatures are brought in by the weekend.The blustery conditions come after a hot summer that brought in the driest June on record.Meteorologist Emma Smith said Tuesdays cloudy conditions were expected to continue into Wednesday.She said: It will be largely cloudy across the country, with outbreaks of patchy rain where the clouds are thickest.Wednesday will be the warmest day of the week with temperatures reaching 28 or 29C.But by Thursday, a cold front will push across Devon and Cornwall north - bringing with it blustery showers.Ms Smith said: Showers will become more widespread across Thursday, Friday and Saturday, with the main risk of hail and thunder in the north of the country.Its the first real autumnal change we have seen, its a real change in the type of weather.Overnight temperatures will cool down to 12C.The showers are expected to persist into Saturday and Sunday, with Ms Smith saying: On Sunday, there a chance we will see more persistent rain move into the west.By Bank Holiday Monday we will have unsettled conditions with showers and outbreaks of rain in the northwest.Forecasters have said the August 27 holiday will bring a typically British mix of sunshine and showers.A North/South split will roughly divide the country — with more rain and wind in the North and sunnier spells in the South.This will be the case throughout the long weekend as parts of the North West especially face heavy showers at times.In a forecast from 20 August, the Met Office warned: For Bank Holiday Monday, it is most likely to be unsettled in the northwest, with longer spells of rain and some strong winds.Drier and brighter conditions are generally likely in the South and East.This North West, South East split is then quite likely to continue.

title: jeremy corbyn aide oust pro israel mp guide
story: Nicolette Petersen, 61, has been at Mr Corbyn’s side since 1994 and wrote a how-to-guide to help voters rid Parliament of MPs who support Israel.Our revelation last night sparked fresh claims that the under-fire Labour boss is willing to tolerate anti-Jewish prejudice in his inner circle.In a pamphlet written before the 2010 Election, Mrs Petersen urged Labour supporters to support other parties if the Labour candidate was a “friend of Israel.”Her guide was published in the Spring 2010 edition of the Palestinian News magazine published by the Palestinian Solidarity Campaign - when her boss was a patron of the anti-Israel group.It says: “Read the Jewish Chronicle on line and look at websites that will show you who not to vote for.”Last night the Editor of the Jewish Chronicle blasted the guide saying: “This isn’t about helping Palestinians. It’s about attacking Jews.”Stephen Pollard told The Sun: “The recommendation that activists who want to rid Parliament of Zionists use the Jewish Chronicle for a hit-list of targets exposes the truth: that they use the word Zionist as a euphemism for Jew.A Labour Party spokesman said: “We don’t comment on staffing matters.”The latest anti-semitism howler came as Mr Corbyn claimed he “could not remember” if he had shared a takeaway with bloodthirsty boss of Hamas following The Sun’s revelations that he had bragged about it.Despite recounting the long dinner in a 2010 column for the communist Morning Star newspaper, yesterday Mr Corbyn told reporters A takeaway dinner? I dont remember any takeaway dinners.I have met many people from many aspects of the Palestinian cause as a way of bringing about dialogue, as a way of bringing about peace.During a visit to Scotland, the veteran lefty was also probed about comments made by former Labour MP Jim Sheridan who said he had lost “respect and empathy” for Jews because of the antisemitism crisis.Mr Corbyn said: Its completely wrong what he said. He did withdraw it later on, he has been suspended from membership, there will be an independent investigation - independent of me that is - so I cant comment any further. We do not tolerate anti-Semitism in any form, in our party or anywhere in our society. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa mays electoral prospects depend on how she deals with mass uncontrolled immigration post brexit
story: As usual, she’ll be more focused on the advice of civil servants than her own colleagues or the guidance from her Chief Whip or the wider Cabinet.She would be unwise to ignore the evidence from polls and her own MPs, that the settled opinion of the country is simply “thus far and no further” and that instead the best way to get back onto the front foot is to work up more concessions to the EU and specifically, surrendering the last major red line: On mass uncontrolled immigration via free movement.We can see clues of further surrender in the fuzzy language from the Chequers agreement: The Government is commitment to “allowing citizens to travel freely without a visa, for tourism and temporary business activity…” But what will “temporary” really mean? Will our current free movement regime be rebadged as a “Labour Mobility Framework”?Such a move, speculated on in the media this week, would be politically toxic and very poorly timed. It would also betray her own instincts, which she rightly gave voice to when she became Prime Minister.Striking a chord with millions of people angry and alienated at their voices being ignored by the political elite on immigration and the downside of globalisation, delivered for her record poll ratings then and a real feeling of hope that at last people in power were listening.Yes, the main driver for the Leave vote was about democracy, independence and national sovereignty but it was also about the fundamental choice that a UK outside the EU would have: Who comes to our country and on what basis – decided by our own Parliament.Voters have noticed that the tightening of the labour market and record employment levels, as revealed by the Office for National Statistics last week, mean that at long last real wages – i.e. pay packets less inflation – are slowly rising and that belatedly big business is beginning to move away from an over reliance on cheap foreign labour, undercutting the pay and conditions of indigenous workers and giving rise to higher welfare dependency.It might seem a radical concept, but such employers might just have to pay workers decent wages, train them better, improve their skills and try hard to retain them. That’s why EU workers are still coming to the UK in huge numbers, despite ridiculous Project Fear stories to the contrary.So yes – Brexit will mean higher pay for British workers! Top businessman Stuart Rose, briefly spokesman for the Remain campaign, accurately predicted such a development before the EU Referendum.Regrettably, the multinationals’ trades union, the CBI didn’t get the message: No surprise that they now want no restrictions on foreign workers post Brexit – in other words an endless pool of cheap labour just like now.Likewise, they’re happy to defend the growing gap between average pay and that of FTSE 100 bosses.Ironically, The Prime Minister could still snatch victory from defeat on this issue, notwithstanding her lamentable record as Home Secretary on reducing net immigration to the tens of thousands.The alternative White Paper which David Davis and his Ministers were working on prior to it being dumped at Chequers, was much more evidence-based and looked to many workable international examples of mobility agreements between first world countries like Australia, the United States, Japan and Canada, as a model for future EU-UK immigration arrangements, to our mutual benefit.The policy would have been informed by the Migration Advisory Committee which reports next month, focused on what was the sensible policy for the whole of the UK and all business sectors rather than a noisy minority and their well-paid advocates.It also sought to end the systemic bias towards low paid and low skilled EU citizens over the well qualified from across the globe.It was pro controlled immigration and not about pulling up the drawbridge and that’s where most British voters are now.Will Theresa May use the opportunity to keep faith with the millions of people in the north and the midlands, in south Wales and south west, who look to her to keep her promises and defend their interests and not just those of the well heeled, the multinationals and those comfortable with the Brussels status quo?Will putative leadership contender Sajid Javid have the courage to resist further attempts at craven supplication on continuing free movement in all but name? Will Conservative MPs who benefited from the highest ever blue collar vote for their party in history, ignore their own electors’ concerns and just accept further concessions?The electoral prospects of her party depend on it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
